node.title: NYC Lawmakers Set to Decide Whether to Prohibit New Buildings From Using Natural Gas
node.description: The proposal would require most construction projects in a few years to forgo natural gas in favor of electricity or other more climate-friendly sources.

node.title: Facing Questions on Spiking Crime, California's Gavin Newsom Deflects Attention to Texas
node.description: The California governor has suggested creating gun legislation styled after the Lone Star State's controversial abortion law.

node.title: Keechant Sewell, NYC's 1st Female Police Commissioner, Plans to Crack Down on Gun Crimes
node.description: New York City Mayor-elect Eric Adams announced Wednesday his choice to appoint Keechant Sewell as police commissioner, with both starting their roles in January.

node.title: Northland checkpoints start smoothly as Auckland border reopens
node.description: Police plan to remove the Northland Covid-19 compliance checkpoints in five days, then switch to roving checks like those being done in other parts of the country. Audio

node.title: The Omicron Covid-19 variant: What you need to know
node.description: Explainer - The Omicron variant of Covid-19 is rapidly spreading around the world. Here's what you need to know about the risk the variant poses and its possible impact on the global pandemic… Video

node.title: Police seize 16,000 rounds of ammunition, 17 firearms in Marlborough
node.description: Police seized 16,000 rounds of ammunition and 17 firearms, many of which they say are banned, in the Marlborough town of Crail Bay last week.

node.title: C.D.C. Virus Tests Were Contaminated and Poorly Designed, Agency Says
node.description: An internal review documented two serious flaws in the test kits, which were distributed to public health laboratories in early 2020.

node.title: Met Opera to Mandate Booster Shots for Staff and Audiences
node.description: It is the first major performing arts institution to require boosters, as concern mounts over rising coronavirus cases and the spread of the Omicron variant. The rule will take effect Jan. 17.

node.title: Federal Reserve Will Pull Back Economic Help More Quickly as Inflation Accelerates
node.description: Federal Reserve officials suggested as many as three interest rate increases in 2022 as the economy heals and inflation persists.

node.title: U.S. Waited Months to Book C.I.A. Prisoners at Guantánamo Bay
node.description: Defense lawyers said the delay cast into doubt whether samples taken from the captives could be considered valid evidence.

node.title: Texas’s Fight Over School Books
node.description: “At what point do I practice subversion?” a teacher wondered.

node.title: Many Turks Can’t Afford Bread, and Bakers Can’t Afford to Make It
node.description: Squeezed by rising costs, price controls and plunging sales, bakers warn of ruin, while their impoverished former customers line up for government-supplied loaves.

node.title: 'Significant' Amounts of Water Discovered Under Mars Grand Canyon Feature in Historic Find
node.description: This recent finding signified that the Red Planet could contain deeper water stores covered by dust.

node.title: Kim Potter Trial: Cops Have Been Known to Confuse Tasers With Guns, Expert Testifies
node.description: Sergeant Mike Peterson, a use-of-force expert, testified that officers are allowed to use their Taser if someone is physically resisting police or is violent.

node.title: 'Enough Is Enough': House Passes Anti-Islamophobia Bill in Response to Rep. Lauren Boebert
node.description: The bill comes after Boebert allegedly refused to apologize for anti-Muslim rhetoric claiming Representative Ilhan Omar was a terrorist.

node.title: Launceston airport sues agency over lack of PFAS plan
node.description: Potentially toxic firefighting chemicals were found in fish pulled from a river near Launceston Airport two years ago. Now the airport is taking legal action to make the government do something about it.

node.title: Federal Reserve set to announce interest-rate moves
node.description: Most economists expect the Fed to begin its shift from propping up the pandemic economy to tackling surging inflation.

node.title: Elfrida von Nardroff, 96, Dies; Won Big Money on a Fixed Quiz Show
node.description: In 1958, she won more on “Twenty-One” than anyone else. But she became embroiled in a scandal that led to grand jury and congressional investigations.

node.title: 3 Residents of The Villages in Florida Are Accused of Voting Fraud
node.description: All were residents of the famed, sprawling retirement community northwest of Orlando. Two were Republicans, and one had no affiliation.

node.title: Iran to Reinstall Cameras at Nuclear Site but With Limited Access, U.N. Watchdog Says
node.description: Iran agreed to allow the IAEA to reinstall cameras at the Karaj nuclear facility after previously refusing to replace cameras damaged in a June attack.

node.title: Ashley is usually the only female carpenter on site — a new $57m program aims to change that
node.description: Women tradies, who make up about 2 per cent of workers on construction sites in NSW, welcome an injection of more than $50 million to boost numbers, saying it's a step towards making women on sites the norm.

node.title: Modelling predicting 25,000 COVID cases a day by January in NSW was 'very preliminary'
node.description: The author of the COVID modelling report used by the NSW Health Minister to urge the community to stay vigilant ahead of a surge in cases backs his findings but says they were very preliminary.

node.title: Pardon backlog frustrates thousands seeking to clear their names
node.description: "Everywhere I go there will be background checks and I don't want that to be a hindrance for my future," one woman says.

node.title: U.S. releases hundreds of new JFK assassination documents
node.description: The documents include thousands of pages of never-before-seen investigative memos, notes and cables.

node.title: The Dream of U.S.-Made Computer Chips
node.description: Before we invest in making more chips on U.S. soil, we should be asking what we’re trying to achieve.

node.title: La Palma Volcano Goes Silent After Three Months of Daily Eruptions
node.description: The Cumbre Vieja volcano first erupted on September 19 and has covered about 3,000 acres of the island with hardened lava.

node.title: Grindr Fined $7M Over Sharing Users' Personal Data With Potential Ad Partners
node.description: A 2020 complaint accused the dating app company of providing third parties with user information like GPS locations, addresses, ages, gender and app use.

node.title: Federal Labor calls for 'failed app' to be ditched after finding just two close contacts in six months
node.description: From mid-May to mid-November, when there were major outbreaks and lockdowns across New South Wales and Victoria, just 13 people consented to their data being used for contact tracing.

node.title: One question everyone asks at Ghislaine Maxwell's trial may never be answered
node.description: Ghislaine Maxwell’s trial has given the world a glimpse of her deeply weird and luxurious life with Jeffrey Epstein, but the mystery at the core of this saga may never be solved.

node.title: How a cocaine kingpin infiltrated the horseracing industry, and how it could happen again
node.description: An ABC investigation reveals how weak regulation allowed cocaine kingpin Damion Flower to help bankroll Australia's richest horse race, even though his horse business was running at a loss.
